Getting Started — Simple Examples


To get started without a any big effort, a set of basic sample applications has been prepared, all of which are fully documented. The provided source code of these samples is meant to be very simple and self-explaining.


Basic Examples for the Target Positon-based Algorithm

  • Example 1 — Introduction to the Position-based algorithm
    A first application using the position-based Online Trajectory Generation (OTG) algorithm:
    • Setting-up input values RMLPositionInputParameters and
    • calling the algorithm ReflexxesAPI::RMLPosition().

  • Example 2 — Making Use of Output Parameters of the Position-based algorithm
    The same as Example 1, but in addition, the entire set of output values of the algorithm are used and described

  • Example 3 — Different Synchronization Behaviors of the Position-based algorithm
    This sample application shows the difference between time- and phase-synchronized motion trajectories and how they can be specified (cf. Synchronization Behavior). The use of the input flag RMLFlags::SynchronizationBehavior is demonstrated.

Basic Examples for the Target Velocity-based Algorithm

  • Example 4 — Introduction to the Velocity-based algorithm
    Similar to Example 1; a first application using the target velocity-based Online Trajectory Generation algorithm:
    • Setting-up input values RMLVelocityInputParameters and
    • calling the algorithm ReflexxesAPI::RMLVelocity().

  • Example 5 — Making Use of Output Parameters of the Velocity-based algorithm
    The same as Example 4, but in addition, the entire set of output values of the algorithm are used and described.

  • Example 6 — Different Synchronization Behaviors of the Velocity-based algorithm
    Similar to Example 4, but here, a time-synchronized trajectory is generated. The use of the input flag RMLFlags::SynchronizationBehavior is demonstrated.

Examples for Using the Minimum Synchronization Time

  • Example 7 — Making Use of the Optional Parameter MinimumSynchronizationTime for the Position-based Algorithm
    The same as Example 2, but in addition, the optional input value RMLInputParameters::MinimumSynchronizationTime is used and described.

  • Example 8 — Making Use of the Optional Parameter MinimumSynchronizationTime for the Velocity-based Algorithm
    The same as Example 5, but in addition, the optional input value RMLInputParameters::MinimumSynchronizationTime is used and described.

Examples for the Using Positional Limits

  • Example 9 — Handling Positional Limits with the Position-based Algorithm (Error Message Only)
    In addition to Example 1, positional limits are specified and the input flag RMLFlags::POSITIONAL_LIMITS_ERROR_MSG_ONLY is used.

  • Example 10 — Handling Positional Limits with the Position-based Algorithm (Active Limit Prevention)
    Same example as Example 9; here, the input flag RMLFlags::POSITIONAL_LIMITS_ACTIVELY_PREVENT is used.

  • Example 11 — Handling Positional Limits with the Velocity-based Algorithm (Error Message Only)
    In addition to Example 4, positional limits are specified and the input flag RMLFlags::POSITIONAL_LIMITS_ERROR_MSG_ONLY is used.

  • Example 12 — Handling Positional Limits with the Velocity-based Algorithm (Active Limit Prevention)
    Same example as Example 11; here, the input flag RMLFlags::POSITIONAL_LIMITS_ACTIVELY_PREVENT is used.

Examples for Using the Override Functionality

  • Example 13 — Using the Override Functionality (Position-based Example)
    Similar example to Example 1, but in addition, the override functionality of the Reflexxes Motion Libraries is used, and two different override values are applied.

  • Example 14 — Using the Override Functionality (Velocity-based Example)
    Similar example to Example 4, but in addition, the override functionality of the Reflexxes Motion Libraries is used, and two different override values are applied.

Examples for Using the C-wrapper

  • Example 15 — Using the C-wrapper for the Reflexxes Motion Library (Position-based Example)
    Same example as Example 1, but instead of the C++ API provided through the class ReflexxesAPI, the C-API provided in the file TypeIVRML_C_Wrapper.h is used.

  • Example 16 — Using the C-wrapper for the Reflexxes Motion Library (Velocity-based Example)
    Same example as Example 4, but instead of the C++ API provided through the class ReflexxesAPI, the C-API provided in the file TypeIVRML_C_Wrapper.h is used.

All resulting trajectories are shown together with the source code files. Within a source code file, you may click on the links of the used data structures to learn more about the Reflexxes API.
